natural problem:
Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
natural solution: The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.

Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).

We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.

Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real*real" 
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "M = ((fst B + fst C)/2, (snd B + snd C)/2)"
and h4 : "area_triangle A B C = 70"
and h5 : "slope_line A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
 The final Answer is 47
 ### Proof
 The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.
 Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).
 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real*real" 
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "M = ((fst B + fst C)/2, (snd B + snd C)/2)"
and h4 : "area_triangle A B C = 70"
and h5 : "slope_line A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let $A$, $B$, and $C$ be points in the plane, with $B = (12, 19)$, $C = (23, 20)$, and $A = (p, q)$ for some real numbers $p$ and $q$. Let $M$ be the midpoint of $BC$. If the area of triangle $ABC$ is 70 and the slope of the line $AM$ is -5, find the value of $p + q$. The final answer is 47.

a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
 The final Answer is 47
 ### Proof
 The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.
 Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).
 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "let B = (12, 19); C = (23, 20); A = (p, q); M = ((B[1] + C[1]) / 2, (B[2] + C[2]) / 2) in
              abs((A[1]*(B[2] - C[2]) + B[1]*(C[2] - A[2]) + C[1]*(A[2] - B[2])) / 2) = 70"
and h1 : "let B = (12, 19); C = (23, 20); A = (p, q); M = ((B[1] + C[1]) / 2, (B[2] + C[2]) / 2) in
              (q - M[2]) / (p - M[1]) = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with B(12, 19), C(23, 20) and the midpoint M of BC, the area of triangle ABC is 70 square units and the slope of line AM is -5. Find the coordinates of point A(p, q) such that p + q = 47.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: real and A B C M :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h1 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h2 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h3 : "A = (p, q)"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$

 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.

 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.

theorem
fixes p q :: real and A B C M :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h1 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h2 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h3 : "A = (p, q)"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a triangle with vertices A, B, and C, the area of the triangle is 70 square units. The coordinates of vertex B are (12, 19) and those of vertex C are (23, 20). Vertex A has coordinates (p, q). The midpoint, M, of the line segment BC has a slope of -5 when connected to vertex A. Find the sum of coordinates p and q for vertex A. The final answer is 47.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real" and slope_m :: real and area :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area = 70"
and h4 : "M = ((fst B + fst C) / 2, (snd B + snd C) / 2)"
and h5 : "slope_m = -5"
and h6 : "area = (\<bar> (fst B - fst A) * (snd C - snd A) - (fst C - fst A) * (snd B - snd A) \<bar>) / 2"
and h7 : "snd M - snd A = slope_m * (fst M - fst A)"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real" and slope_m :: real and area :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area = 70"
and h4 : "M = ((fst B + fst C) / 2, (snd B + snd C) / 2)"
and h5 : "slope_m = -5"
and h6 : "area = (\<bar> (fst B - fst A) * (snd C - snd A) - (fst C - fst A) * (snd B - snd A) \<bar>) / 2"
and h7 : "snd M - snd A = slope_m * (fst M - fst A)"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a triangle with vertices $B(12, 19)$, $C(23, 20)$, and $A(p, q)$, the midpoint $M$ of the side $BC$ lies on a line with slope $-5$. If the area of the triangle is $70$ square units, find the sum $p+q$. The final answer is $47$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "line_slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_4.formal solution:

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "line_slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a triangle with vertices $B(12, 19)$, $C(23, 20)$, and $A(p, q)$, where the area of the triangle is 70 and the midpoint $M$ of segment $BC$ has a slope of -5 with respect to point $A$. Find the sum of the coordinates $p + q$. The final answer is 47.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and slope_median :: real
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope_median = (snd A - snd M) / (fst A - fst M)"
and h6 : "slope_median = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and slope_median :: real
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "triangle_area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope_median = (snd A - snd M) / (fst A - fst M)"
and h6 : "slope_median = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, vertices $B$ and $C$ have coordinates $(12, 19)$ and $(23, 20)$, respectively. The area of the triangle is $70$ square units. The median from vertex $A$ to the midpoint $M$ of side $BC$ has a slope of $-5$. If the coordinates of vertex $A$ are $(p, q)$, find the value of $p + q$. The final answer is $47$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and area :: real
and slope :: real
assumes h0 : "area = 70"
and h1 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h2 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h3 : "A = (p, q)"
and h4 : "M = ((fst B + fst C) / 2, (snd B + snd C) / 2)"
and h5 : "slope = -5"
and h6 : "area_triangle A B C = area"
and h7 : "slope_line A M = slope"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and area :: real
and slope :: real
assumes h0 : "area = 70"
and h1 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h2 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h3 : "A = (p, q)"
and h4 : "M = ((fst B + fst C) / 2, (snd B + snd C) / 2)"
and h5 : "slope = -5"
and h6 : "area_triangle A B C = area"
and h7 : "slope_line A M = slope"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with vertices A(p, q), B(12, 19), and C(23, 20), the midpoint M of side BC is calculated as $M=\left(\frac{12+23}{2}, \frac{19+20}{2}\right)$. The triangle has an area of 70 square units, and the slope of the line AM is -5. Find the sum of the coordinates p and q of vertex A. The final answer is 47.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area_triangle A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
 The final Answer is 47
 ### Proof
 The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.
 Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).
 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real"
and p q :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area_triangle A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given points B (12, 19) and C (23, 20), find the coordinates of point A (p, q) such that the area of triangle ABC is 70, the midpoint M of segment BC has a slope of -5 with point A, and the sum of p and q is 47.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real" and p q :: real and slope :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope = (snd A - snd M) / (fst A - fst M)"
and h6 : "slope = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
 The final Answer is 47
 ### Proof
 The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.
 Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).
 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C M :: "real * real" and p q :: real and slope :: real
assumes h0 : "B = (12, 19)"
and h1 : "C = (23, 20)"
and h2 : "A = (p, q)"
and h3 : "area A B C = 70"
and h4 : "M = midpoint B C"
and h5 : "slope = (snd A - snd M) / (fst A - fst M)"
and h6 : "slope = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Let $A$, $B$, and $C$ be points in the plane with coordinates $A(p, q)$, $B(12, 19)$, and $C(23, 20)$. Suppose the area of triangle $ABC$ is 70, and let $M$ be the midpoint of $BC$. If the slope of the line through points $A$ and $M$ is $-5$, find the value of $p + q$. The final answer is 47.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "let A = (p, q); B = (12, 19); C = (23, 20); M = ((B[1] + C[1]) / 2, (B[2] + C[2]) / 2) in 
area_triangle A B C = 70 \<and> slope_line A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Triangle $ABC$ lies in the cartesian plane and has an area of $70$. The coordinates of $B$ and $C$ are $(12,19)$ and $(23,20),$ respectively, and the coordinates of $A$ are $(p,q).$ The line containing the median to side $BC$ has slope $-5.$ Find the largest possible value of $p+q.$
[asy]defaultpen(fontsize(8)); size(170); pair A=(15,32), B=(12,19), C=(23,20), M=B/2+C/2, P=(17,22); draw(A--B--C--A);draw(A--M);draw(B--P--C); label("A (p,q)",A,(1,1));label("B (12,19)",B,(-1,-1));label("C (23,20)",C,(1,-1));label("M",M,(0.2,-1)); label("(17,22)",P,(1,1)); dot(A^^B^^C^^M^^P);[/asy]
 The final Answer is 47
 ### Proof
 The midpoint $M$ of line segment $\overline{BC}$ is $\left(\frac{35}{2}, \frac{39}{2}\right)$. The equation of the median can be found by $-5 = \frac{q - \frac{39}{2}}{p - \frac{35}{2}}$. Cross multiply and simplify to yield that $-5p + \frac{35 \cdot 5}{2} = q - \frac{39}{2}$, so $q = -5p + 107$.
 Use determinants to find that the area of $\triangle ABC$ is $\frac{1}{2} \begin{vmatrix}p & 12 & 23 \\  q & 19 & 20 \\ 1 & 1 & 1\end{vmatrix} = 70$ (note that there is a missing absolute value; we will assume that the other solution for the triangle will give a smaller value of $p+q$, which is provable by following these steps over again).
 We can calculate this determinant to become $140 = \begin{vmatrix} 12 & 23 \\ 19 & 20 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 23 & 20 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} p & q \\ 12 & 19 \end{vmatrix}$ $\Longrightarrow 140 = 240 - 437 - 20p + 23q + 19p - 12q$ $= -197 - p + 11q$.
 Thus, $q = \frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11}$. Setting this equation equal to the equation of the median, we get that $\frac{1}{11}p - \frac{337}{11} = -5p + 107$, so $\frac{56}{11}p = \frac{107 \cdot 11 + 337}{11}$.
 Solving produces that $p = 15$.
 Substituting backwards yields that $q = 32$; the solution is $p + q = \boxed{47}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p q :: real
assumes h0 : "let A = (p, q); B = (12, 19); C = (23, 20); M = ((B[1] + C[1]) / 2, (B[2] + C[2]) / 2) in 
area_triangle A B C = 70 \<and> slope_line A M = -5"
shows  "p + q = 47"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with points B(12, 19), C(23, 20), and a midpoint M of BC, if the area of the triangle is 70 and the slope of the line passing through point A and M is -5, find the sum of the coordinates of point A. The final answer is 47.
